case_name: Masud Khan v. Union of India

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 117 of 1973 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 117 of 1973. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of a writ in the nature of have as companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner Masud Khan prays for release claiming illegal arrest and confinement under Paragraph 5 of the Foreigners Internment Order, 1962

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner Masud Khan prays for his release on the ground that he, an Indian citizen has been illegally arrested and companyfined to, jail under Paragraph 5 of the Foreigners  Internment  Order, 1962.

facts.text: Petitioner came to India from Pakistan on Pakistani passport dated 13-7-1954 and Indian visa dated 9-4-1956

anchor.surface_text: He had companye to India from Pakistan on the basis of a Pakistani passport dated 13- 7-1954 and Indian visa dated 9-4-1956.

facts.text: In visa application, petitioner stated he migrated to Pakistan in 1948, was in Government service in P.W.D. as Darogha, permanent address Hyderabad Sind

anchor.surface_text: In his application for visa he had stated that he had migrated to Pakistan in 1948 and was in Government service in Pakistan in P.W.D. as a Darogha and had given his permanent address as Hyderabad  Sind .

facts.text: Petitioner filed further affidavit claiming appointed as Police Constable in Hasanganj Police Station, District Fatehpur, UP in February 1947, continued till middle of 1950, dismissed, went to Pakistan in 1951

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner filed a further affidavit stating that he was appointed as a Police Constable in Hasanganj Police Station, District Fatehpur, P. in February 1947 and companytinued as a Police Constable till the middle of 1950 when he was dismissed from service, and that he went to Pakistan in the year 1951.

facts.text: Respondent's reply affidavit states Md. Masood Khan son of Zahoor Khan enrolled as Police Constable on 16-9-1947 and discharged on 20-5-1949 from English Order Book 1-10-1947 to 27-12-1951

anchor.surface_text: In the reply affidavit filed on behalf of the respondent it is stated that one Md. Masood Khan son of Zahoor Khan was enrolled as Police Constable on 16-9-1947 and he was discharged from service on 20-5-1949. It is fairly clear that this information culled from the English Order Book from 1-10- 1947 to 27-12-1951 refers to the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner did not go to Pakistan in 1948

anchor.surface_text: While, therefore, it is established that the petitioner did number go to Pakistan in 1948, it cannot be said that it has been established that the petitioner went to Pakistan only in 1951.

facts.text: Petitioner did not produce evidence to support going to Pakistan in 1951

anchor.surface_text: When he went to Pakistan is a matter peculiarly within his knowledge and the produced numberevidence in support of that statement.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged married in U.P. on 25th December, 1949

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has also alleged that he was married in U.P. on 25th December, 1949.

facts.text: Petitioner failed to establish presence in India on 26-1-1950

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that this statement is companyrect, the petitioner cannot establish that he is a citizen of India unless lie succeeds in establishing that he was in India on 26-1-1950.

facts.text: Petitioner prosecuted in 1960 before Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Fatehpur under s.14 of Foreigners Act and acquitted on ground not a foreigner

anchor.surface_text: It appears, however, that in 1960 he had been prosecuted before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Fatehpur under s. 14 of the Foreigner--, Act and was acquitted on the ground that he was number a foreigner.

facts.text: Petitioner's 1960 acquittal based on Allahabad High Court decision in Mohd. Hanif Khan v. State AIR 1960 All. 434

anchor.surface_text: The decision that he was number a foreigner seems to have been based on the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Mohd. Hanif Khan v. State  AIR 1960 All. 434 .

facts.text: Mohd. Hanif Khan decision differed from Ali Sher v. The State AIR 1960 All. 431

anchor.surface_text: It was held there that a Pakistani national who entered into India before the amendment to the Foreigners Act in 1957, when he companyld number be companysidered to be a foreigner, companyld number be so held because of that amendment. That decision was that of a learned Single Judge. On the point at issue he differed from an earlier decision of a learned Single Judge of the same Court in Ali Sher v. The State  AIR 1960 All. 431 .

facts.text: Court holds petitioner is a foreigner as burden under s-9 Foreigners Act not discharged

anchor.surface_text: Under s-9 of the Foreigners Act whenever a question arises whether a person is or is number a foreigner the onus of proving that he is number a foreigner lies upon him. The burden is therefore, upon the petitioner to establish that be is a citizen of India in the manner claimed by him and therefore be is number a foreigner

facts.text: Petition dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The petition is dismissed.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

facts.text: Petitioner claims Indian citizen

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that he, an Indian citizen has been illegally arrested

facts.text: Petitioner resorted to frequent change of ground regarding date to Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: Considering the frequent change of ground which the petitioner has resorted to, a mere statement from him cannot be accepted as true.

facts.text: Issue estoppel does not apply as present proceeding not criminal prosecution

anchor.surface_text: Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions. In the present case while the earlier one was a criminal prosecution the present is merely an action taken, under the Foreigners  Internment  Order for the purpose of deporting the petitioner out of India. It is number a criminal prosecution.

arguments.claim: Principle of issue estoppel from SC cases (Pritam Singh, etc.) precludes relitigation only in subsequent criminal proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The principle of issue estoppel is simply this that where an issue of fact has been tried by a companypetent companyrt on a former occasion and a finding has been reached in favour of an accused, such a finding would companystitute an estoppel or res judicata against the prosecution number as a bar to the trial and companyviction of the accused for a different or distinct offence but as precluding the reception of evidence to disturb that finding of fact when the accused is tried subsequently, even for a different offence which might be permitted by law.

holdings.text: There is no room for any presumption that the petitioner was present in India on 26-1-1950.

holdings.text: Under Section 9 of the Foreigners Act, the onus of proving that a person is not a foreigner lies upon him; the petitioner has not discharged this burden and is therefore a foreigner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner failed to prove presence in India on 26-1-1950 due to lack of evidence, inconsistent statements, and failure to produce proof despite matter being within his knowledge.

holdings.text: Issue estoppel does not arise as the present proceedings under the Foreigners Internment Order are not a criminal prosecution, unlike the prior acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions. In the present case while the earlier one was a criminal prosecution the present is merely an action taken, under the Foreigners  Internment  Order for the purpose of deporting the petitioner out of India. It is number a criminal prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of issue estoppel, as explained in Supreme Court precedents (Pritam Singh, etc.), applies only between criminal prosecutions; current internment for deportation is administrative.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention of issue estoppel; the petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: If he bad been in India on 26-1-1950 but had gone to Pakistan in 1951 it would be for the Central Government to decide whether he is a Pakistani national or an Indian citizen even though he may have companye to India on a Pakistani passport in 1956  See AIR 1963 SC 645 AIR 1962 SC 1052 AIR 1962 SC 1778 AIR 1961 SC 1467 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government to decide whether a person is Pakistani national or Indian citizen if in India on 26-1-1950 but gone to Pakistan later even entering on Pakistani passport

precedents.cited_proposition: Earlier decision differing on point of nationality of person entering India on Pakistani passport before 1957

anchor.surface_text: The question of issue-estoppel has been companysidered by this Court in Pritam Singh v. State,of Punjab  AIR 1956 SC 415 , Manipur Administration v. Thokchom, Bira Singh  1964 7 SCR 123  and Piara Singh S. State of Punjab  1969 1 SCC 379 . Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions.

precedents.case_name: Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Issue-estoppel arises only if earlier and subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions

Thokchom, Bira Singh  1964 7 SCR 123  and Piara Singh S. State of Punjab  1969 1 SCC 379 . Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions.

precedents.case_name: Manipur Administration v. Thokchom Bira Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Issue-estoppel arises only if earlier and subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions

anchor.surface_text: The question of issue-estoppel has been companysidered by this Court in Pritam Singh v. State,of Punjab  AIR 1956 SC 415 , Manipur Administration v. Thokchom, Bira Singh  1964 7 SCR 123  and Piara Singh S. State of Punjab  1969 1 SCC 379 . Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions.

precedents.case_name: Piara Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Issue-estoppel arises only if earlier and subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singhs case  supra  was based on the decision of the Privy Council in Sambasivam v. Public, Prosecutor, Federation of Malaya  1950 A.C. 458 . In that case Lord MacDermott speaking for the Board said The effect of a verdict of acquittal pronounced by a companypetent companyrt on a lawful charge and after a lawful trial is number companypletely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence.

precedents.case_name: Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federation of Malaya
precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of acquittal verdict is binding and conclusive in subsequent proceedings between parties in criminal context
precedents.cited_holding: The effect of a verdict of acquittal pronounced by a competent court on a lawful charge and after a lawful trial is not completely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence. To that it must be added that the verdict is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties to the adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: In The King v. Wilkes  77 L.R. 511  Divon, J. referring to the question of issue- estoppel said. 79 6 view that there is an issue estoppel, if it appears by record of itself or as explained by proper evidence, that the same point was determined in favour of a prisoner in a previous criminal trial which is brought in issue on a second criminal trial of the same prisoners

precedents.cited_proposition: Issue estoppel where same point determined in favour of prisoner in previous criminal trial raised in second criminal trial

anchor.surface_text: In Marz v. The Queen  96 C.L.R. 62  the High Court of Australia said The Crown is as much precluded by an estoppel by judgment in criminal proceedings as is a subject in civil proceedings The laws which gives effect to issueestoppel is number companycerned with the companyrectness or incorrectness of the finding which amounts to an estoppel, still less with the process of reasoning by which the finding was reached . in fact It is enough that an issue or issues have been distinctly raised or found.

precedents.cited_proposition: Crown precluded by estoppel by judgment in criminal proceedings; issue estoppel not concerned with correctness of finding but that issue was raised or found
